@mrry @jart @benoitsteiner I do think the issue may need to be addressed one way or another, either stick with numpy or stick with <math.h>' fmax().

The reason is that std::max() is mathematically problematic:

std::max(1., nan) != std::max(nan, 1.)

std::max(1., nan) == std::min(1, nan)

I can help with PR if TensorFlow team can provide direction guidance.

body:
@mrry @jart @benoitsteiner I do think the issue may need to be addressed one way or another, either stick with `numpy` or stick with `<math.h>`' `fmax()`.

The reason is that `std::max()` is mathematically problematic:
```
std::max(1., nan) != std::max(nan, 1.)

std::max(1., nan) == std::min(1, nan)
```

I can help with PR if TensorFlow team can provide direction guidance.
